revision.comment: IATA code deleted. No IATA code of EHT used for this airport. See http://www.iata.org/publications/Pages/code-search.aspx (retrieved 10th March 2016)
revision.text:
{{For|the football stadium|Pratt & Whitney Stadium at Rentschler Field}} {{Infobox Airport | name = Rentschler Field | image = Rentschler Field (Airport) CT - 23 April 1990.jpg | image-width = 250 | caption = {{smaller|Rentschler Field (Airport) on 23 April 1990, before its closure and dismantling. The current-day heliport is at the southwest corner of the airfield, the [[Rentschler Field (stadium)|Rentschler Field]] stadium is at the northeast corner.}} | IATA = EHT{{cite web|url=http://www.iata.org/publications/Pages/code-search.aspx|title=Airline and Airport Code Search| publisher=[[International Air Transport Association|IATA]]|accessdate=10 March 2016}}http://www.theairdb.com/airport/EHT.html | ICAO = | FAA = CT88 | type = Military | owner = ''original:'' [[United States Army]]
''later:'' [[United Technologies]] | operator = | location = [[East Hartford, Connecticut]] | elevation-f = 48 | elevation-m = 15 | coordinates = {{coord|41|45|12|N|072|37|42|W|region:US_type:airport}} | website = | footnotes = Source: [[Federal Aviation Administration]]{{FAA-airport|ID=CT88|use=PR|own=PR|site=02806.*H}}, effective 2008-04-10 }} '''Rentschler Field''' {{Airport codes|EHT||CT88}} was an airport in [[East Hartford, Connecticut]] in use from 1933 to 1999. Originally a military facility, later a private corporate airport, it was decommissioned in 1999, after which the [[Rentschler Field (stadium)|football stadium of the same name]] was built on the site. From 1930 to 1939, the [[Vought|Chance Vought Aircraft Corporations]]'s manufacturing facility was located here, as was the [[Pratt & Whitney|Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Company]] and the [[Hamilton Standard|Hamilton Standard Propellers Corporation]].http://www.utdallas.edu/library/specialcollections/hac/vought/history.pdf == History == During [[World War II]] the airfield was used by the [[United States Army Air Forces]] [[First Air Force]] as a fighter base, providing coastal air defense over the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. After the war, the airfield was returned to civilian use. Rentschler Field was decommissioned as an airport and donated to the state of Connecticut by United Technologies in 1999. Part of the former airport became the [[University of Connecticut]]'s new football stadium, [[Rentschler Field (stadium)|Rentschler Field]]. == See also == * [[Connecticut World War II Army Airfields]] == References == {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * Thole, Lou (1999), Forgotten Fields of America : World War II Bases and Training, Then and Now - Vol. 2. Publisher: Pictorial Histories Pub, ISBN 1-57510-051-7 {{refend}} ==External links== *http://www.airfields-freeman.com/CT/Airfields_CT_C.html#Rentschler [[Category:Airfields of the United States Army Air Forces in Connecticut]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Hartford County, Connecticut]] [[Category:Transportation in Hartford County, Connecticut]] [[Category:1933 establishments in Connecticut]] [[Category:1999 disestablishments in Connecticut]] {{Connecticut-airport-stub}}
